ol.li: B/ \mathfrak {m}B is of finite dimension over k=A/ \mathfrak {m}.

mainmatter.p: If the conditions of are satisfied, then we say that B is quasi-finite over A. A morphism f \colon X \to Y is said to be quasi-finite at x (or the Y-prescheme f is said to be quasi-finite at x) if \mathcal {O}_x is quasi-finite over \mathcal {O}_{f(x)}. This is equivalent to saying that x is isolated in its fibre f^{-1}(x). A morphism is said to be quasi-finite if it is quasi-finite at each point. (In [EGA II 6.2.3] we further suppose that f is of finite type.)
If A is complete, then quasi-finiteness is equivalent to finiteness.
We could also give the usual polysyllogism (i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v) for quasi-finite morphisms, but that doesn't seem necessary here.
